title: THE SPICE MARKET
style_prefix: Children's book illustration, warm painterly style with soft brush strokes. NO TEXT IN IMAGE.

character_refs.riley: Riley - girl with straight dark hair, pink bow, purple dress with white stars

scenes.script: The friends sat in the attic. Mr. Mason held a small pouch. It smelled like spices. 'Let me take you to Morocco,' he said.
scenes.prompt: Attic scene. Friends sitting around Mr. Mason who holds a small cloth spice pouch. Warm golden light. Everyone quiet and attentive, ready for a story.

scenes.script: The attic started to fade. Colors got brighter. They could see a big market. There were stalls everywhere. People walked and talked.
scenes.prompt: Magical transition - attic fading into vibrant Moroccan souk. Colorful market stalls appearing. Warm oranges, reds, golds. Bustling atmosphere emerging.

scenes.script: A young man walked into the market. It was Mr. Mason! He was young. He had dark hair. His eyes were wide.
scenes.prompt: Young Mr. Mason entering the Moroccan souk, eyes wide with wonder. Colorful market surrounds him. Spice stalls, fabrics, crowds. First time amazement.

scenes.script: Young Mr. Mason had a job. He needed to find saffron. His mama asked for it. 'Get the good stuff,' she said.
scenes.prompt: Young Mr. Mason walking through market with purpose. Looking at stalls searching for something. Determined expression. Spice vendors visible.

scenes.script: He found the spice stalls. There were piles of spices. Red ones. Gold ones. Orange ones. They looked like little mountains.
scenes.prompt: Young Mr. Mason at spice stall area. Beautiful cone-shaped piles of colorful spices - red, gold, orange, brown. Mountains of spices. Vibrant colors.

scenes.script: A man ran up to him. 'You buy! Best price!' the man yelled. He was too close. Young Mr. Mason stepped back.
scenes.prompt: Pushy merchant getting too close to young Mr. Mason, gesturing aggressively. Young Mr. Mason stepping back uncomfortable. Crowded market scene.

scenes.script: Young Mr. Mason walked away. He felt bad. He wanted to buy. But he did not like being rushed.
scenes.prompt: Young Mr. Mason walking away from pushy merchant, looking uncertain and uncomfortable. Moving through crowded market. Searching for something better.

scenes.script: Then he saw a quiet stall. An old man sat there. His name was Hassan. He smiled. He did not yell. 'Take your time,' Hassan said.
scenes.prompt: Hassan sitting calmly at his spice stall. Quiet dignified presence amid busy market. Welcoming smile, peaceful demeanor. Young Mr. Mason approaching curiously.

scenes.script: Young Mr. Mason stopped. 'I need saffron,' he said. 'It is for my mama.' Hassan nodded. 'What will she make?'
scenes.prompt: Young Mr. Mason at Hassan's stall, having respectful conversation. Hassan listening attentively. Spices arranged neatly. Calm exchange between them.

scenes.script: Hassan showed him three kinds of saffron. 'This one is good. This one is better. And this one is the best.' He held up the red threads.
scenes.prompt: Hassan holding up three different containers of saffron, showing quality differences. Deep red threads visible. Young Mr. Mason examining with interest. Teaching moment.

scenes.script: Hassan said the price. It was more than Mr. Mason thought. He felt worried. 'That is a lot,' he said softly.
scenes.prompt: Young Mr. Mason looking worried at the price, reaching for his money pouch hesitantly. Hassan watching patiently. Moment of concern.

scenes.script: 'A deal is not a fight,' Hassan said. 'It is a talk. You say what you can pay. I say what I need. We find the middle.'
scenes.prompt: Hassan speaking wisely, gesturing with open hands. Young Mr. Mason listening intently. Wisdom being shared. Respectful negotiation lesson.

scenes.script: They talked more. Young Mr. Mason said a lower price. Hassan came down a little. They found a price they both liked. They shook hands.
scenes.prompt: Young Mr. Mason and Hassan shaking hands with mutual smiles. Both satisfied with the deal. Fair exchange. Respectful agreement.

scenes.script: Hassan wrapped the saffron in paper. He put it in a small pouch. He gave it to Mr. Mason. 'Take this to your mama,' he said.
scenes.prompt: Hassan carefully wrapping saffron in paper, placing it in small cloth pouch. Handing it to young Mr. Mason with care. Precious package.

scenes.script: 'One more thing,' Hassan said. 'Never rush a good thing. Patience shows you care.' Young Mr. Mason nodded.
scenes.prompt: Hassan sharing final wisdom, finger raised gently. Young Mr. Mason nodding respectfully, holding the precious pouch. Important lesson moment.

scenes.script: Young Mr. Mason walked through the market. But now he walked slowly. He looked at things. He smiled. He held the pouch tight.
scenes.prompt: Young Mr. Mason walking peacefully through market, unhurried now. Holding pouch close. Relaxed smile. Seeing the market with new appreciation.

scenes.script: The market started to fade. The colors got soft. They were back in the attic. Mr. Mason was old again. He still held the pouch.
scenes.prompt: Magical transition back - Moroccan colors fading softly. Attic reappearing. Old Mr. Mason now, still holding the same pouch. Past and present connected.

scenes.script: The friends looked at Mr. Mason. Their eyes were big. 'Wow,' said Riley. 'I want to see a market like that!'
scenes.prompt: Friends with amazed expressions looking at Mr. Mason. Riley speaking excitedly. Mr. Mason placing pouch back in trunk with gentle reverence.

scenes.script: Layla was quiet. She was thinking. She always wanted to do things fast. Maybe that was not good. 'I rush too much,' she said softly.
scenes.prompt: Layla with thoughtful introspective expression. Quiet moment of self-reflection. Other friends and Mr. Mason watching her gently. Personal growth moment.

scenes.script: The friends looked at each other. They would have their own market soon. 'We need fair prices,' said Ellis. 'Prices that make everyone happy.'
scenes.prompt: Four friends in discussion, applying the lesson. Ellis speaking, others nodding. Mr. Mason watching approvingly. Planning for their future market.
